plan: In the first round, I'll bid aggressively up to 75% of my prize value to test competitors' strategies. If my value is high (above 30), I'll push closer to my full value, aiming to outbid others and gather data on their limits. In the second round, I'll adjust based on the first round's insights. If opponents bid conservatively, I'll exploit this by increasing my bids slightly above their previous limits. If they bid aggressively, I'll adopt a more cautious approach, withdrawing earlier to minimize potential losses. This will help balance risk and maximize long-term profit.

In Round 1, I'll adopt a conservative strategy, exiting when the bid reaches 75% of my value to gather data on opponents' behavior and bidding limits. In Round 2, I'll shift to an aggressive strategy, staying until 90% of my value to test opponents' reactions and explore potential for higher profit. I'll monitor when opponents drop out to estimate their values and adjust my strategy accordingly. This approach balances risk and reward, leveraging insights from Round 1 to maximize profit in Round 2.

In the first round, I'll bid aggressively up to my full value minus a small buffer (e.g., 2-3 USD) to gather data on Andy's and Betty's bidding tendencies. This will help assess their risk tolerance and value estimation. In the second round, I'll adjust my strategy based on the first round's observations. If they bid conservatively, I'll bid slightly above their previous exit prices. If they bid aggressively, I'll aim for a mid-range bid to maximize profit while minimizing risk. This approach balances exploration and exploitation to optimize long-term profit.

In this round, I'll bid up to 80% of my value. If my value is high, I'll push to 90% to test limits. I'll observe exit points closely, adjusting my strategy accordingly to exploit conservative bids or mitigate aggressive ones, aiming to maximize long-term profit.

In Round 1, exit at 70% of my value to observe opponents' strategies. In Round 2, bid up to 85% of my value, testing their limits and reactions. Adjust based on when they drop out, aiming to refine insights and maximize profit while minimizing risk.

This round, I'll bid up to 13 to test if Andy or Betty exceed 11. If they exit early, I'll secure the win. If they continue, I'll observe their limits for future strategy refinement, balancing risk and potential profit.
